I am not sure if i have enough hours to do this but...

It's simple : Best Battle Royale Ever !
Where start ? So much to say...

Days after days, nights after nights,
months after months, years after years,
sleepless nights after sleepless nights...

Solo, duo, 5s, combat zone, hosted (auto royale, arcade) 

You can join event, private servers, hosted, come play your life. 

Game after game, looting after looting, lag after lag,
fun after fun, dance after dance, missclick after missclick,
rage after rage, tear after tear, laugh after laugh, meets after meets, 

Beautiful story about team killing, crazy people in lobby, crazy win and crazy lose, flying & exploding vehicles, running man in loading screen,

There are also cute butterflies ‚òº

Drive the police car, jump and land on your teammate who is on ATV and kill him by explosion. Try shoot the enemies from the car but it's your teammate who gets hit.

Don't forget to take cover sometimes, choose a good ridge, take care of the camper in the bathtub,
Play in cities, play in the forest, play in the field, play on the roof, play on the bush, dance in the middle of Cranberry with your teammates songs. Stuck the ATV in the building door and then explode. 
Sometimes you take a long time to find people, sometimes it's people who come to you all during the game, like magnets, not even having time to find a military backpack than you won the game.

AR, AK, shotgun, sniper, pistols, fist fight, knife, machete, crossbow & explosive & fire arrows, smoke, molotov, grenade gas, grenade frag, (no speak about MP5...)

Tryhard tryhard, Bullet drop, traveltime, desync...

Chasing or be chasing, codrush or be codrush, 2tap or be 2tap...

*He is dead, he is all dry...*

Crates, so many crates of skins. Outfits and weapons of all colors, even in gold! oulalala! Animated, luminous, sexy weird outfit. Show us the animal that sleeps inside you, dog, panda, yellow head, christmas hat, rabbit, pig, chicken ghillie, turkey ghillie... You can be a pirate, santa claus, deer, unicorn, skull, clown, gorilla, freerunner, demon, snowman, rasta, pumpkins, camo, neko-chan, bandit, desert warfare, nemesis, cop, support your country or your favorite team, LeStram hoodie, FFTC hoodie, T-shirt J!nx and Hizzy Tux, Tan and Racing shorts, white and black anarchy pants, american stuff, Twin Galaxies outfits white, black, pink, camo, Basic grey outfit, dread pirate eyepatch, don't forget beanie or cowbow hat, Skull face bandana, blue, pink, red, clown, camo, chairman blow out party favor, evil clown glasses, red, black, pink... glasses, toxic body armor, toxic gloves, american gloves, plushicorn mili backpack, military backpack make bubbles, Z-wrex, showdown, ASUS RoG, crown, H1PL, royalty, neon splatter backpack, black converse, some emotes, tea, guitar, firework, pray, and much more, also skins for your atv, 2tap, jeep, cop, lamborghini.  Collections of weapons patriotic, toxic, rainbow, unicorn, gold, other shodown AR, PS7, H1PL AR-15, Ninja, frostbite, scorpio, seraph... Infernal shotgun, imperial, nautilus, gold katana, mourning wood, reaver combat knife, 
Some people lost their nerve and break things (keyboard, mouse, screen...) also by betting, lose and win skins in some websites,

Many hours of gaming ‚ô•

And so many other memories since 2017... ‚ô•

‚ô• 2017-2018-2019-2020-2021-2022-2023-...

It's that H1Z1 King Of The Kill, pain & love with addicted people. ‚ô•

[h1] Z1 Battle Royale - Nostalgic Restoration with a Mixed Outcome [/h1]

Overview:
Z1 Battle Royale, formerly known as "King of the Kill," and "H1Z1" has undergone a revitalization, seeking to recapture the essence of its original appeal. This fast-paced, action-packed, free-to-play Battle Royale title returns with a commitment to restore the classic look, feel, and gameplay that once enamored its player base. However, while strides have been made, not all aspects of the revival have resonated positively.

Pros:

Nostalgic Restoration: Z1 Battle Royale successfully taps into nostalgia by reviving the classic elements that players loved from its "King of the Kill" era. The restoration of movement, combat mechanics, and the PS3 era map contributes to a sense of familiarity.

Competitive Gameplay: Staying true to its competitive roots, Z1 Battle Royale offers solo, duos, and fives gameplay, challenging players to be the last ones standing in a fast-paced and action-packed environment.

Major Overhaul: The game has undergone a significant overhaul, addressing concerns from the past and bringing about changes in movement, animations, combat, gun mechanics, and vehicle mechanics.

New Features: The introduction of in-match missions, a fragments/collection system, seasonal play, and a ranked playlist adds fresh elements to the gameplay, enhancing the overall experience.

Showdown Tournament: The announcement of a new Showdown Tournament and the inclusion of all-new rewards provide additional incentives for players to engage in competitive play.

Cons:

Mixed Reception: Despite efforts to restore the classic feel, the reception has been mixed. Some players appreciate the return to the game's roots, while others feel that the core gameplay has declined in recent years.

Deteriorating Appeal: For certain players, the charm that originally drew them to Z1 Battle Royale seems to have diminished over time. Issues related to recent updates and changes have resulted in a less engaging experience.

Competitive Market: The Battle Royale genre is highly competitive, with numerous titles vying for player attention. Z1 Battle Royale faces the challenge of standing out and retaining its player base in an ever-evolving landscape.

Final Thoughts:
Z1 Battle Royale's attempt to recapture the magic of its earlier years is commendable, with a considerable focus on restoration and improvements. While some players may find solace in the nostalgic revival, others might feel that the core gameplay has not kept pace with evolving player expectations. The game's success in the future will likely hinge on its ability to address these concerns while maintaining the classic elements that once made it a standout in the Battle Royale genre.

If your looking for a bajk√∂rv on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie 

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I have so many good memories with this game, i sunk countless hours in the Just survive mode that the game had before it was removed. When this game first came out it was only a survival game there was no battle royal mode to the game, so everyone that paid for the game were buying the just survive edition. Then when these battle royal game game modes that were being  made started becoming really popular daybreak (this games dev team) decided they wanted to make a battle royal mode and add it to the game as an option to play instead of the just survive mode. This was fine with me as i could still play the just survive mode of the game since that was the main reason i bought the game in the first place, after some time passed the battle royal mode to the game started doing really well and was also being streamed on twitch by many popular partnered streamers, this obviously got more and more people to buy the game since everyone wanted to play against these partnered big time streamers. At this point daybreak had decided to split up 2 teams of people and have 1 team work on the battle royal mode of the game while the other team would continue work on the just survive mode of the game. This seemed like a solid plan and again i was fine with it. After some months or so had passed people started noticing that the just survive mode of the game was not getting nearly as much work done to improve it like the battle royal mode of the game was. So of course this caused a pretty big concern for the just survive mode players, daybreak addressed these concerns and told us that just survive would be getting updates still and that it would just take a little longer due to some silly reasons but hey what ever as long as it will still get updates fine. Maybe 3-5 months later after just survive had still received very little updates/fix's the devs came out with another response that basically said they are removing just survive from the game because they want to put all their focus on the battle royal mode of the game. This of course pissed off a lot of people since most people that bought the game got it for it's just survive mode since that was all it had at the start. Now don't get me wrong the battle royal still did pretty well for a while even after just survive mode was removed from the game but over time it did start slowly losing it's player base, in my opinion i feel the reasons the game ended up completely falling apart was due to greedy devs who just wanted money and did not care about screwing over all the people who bought the game for it's just survive mode by removing it from the game and not even offering a refund to people. The game also became littered with cheaters that would of course take over the leader boards, daybreak said they were banning these cheaters but i honestly do not think they banned as many as they claimed they did since a lot of these cheaters remained on the top leader boards for months on end or longer. The player base for the game was also extremely toxic in every way possible. There was a lot of other things that occurred too that were pretty bad. It is honestly really sad that this game fell apart because it was one of the best survival games out there at the time. RIP H1Z1 you are missed greatly.

If you want a lesson on how to disappoint your player base and remove perfectly good game modes that people actually want to play (Just Survive), then you should study the disaster piece of a company that Daybreak is. This is how NOT to make games or manage them. The majority have asked for (Just Survive) and less have asked for Battle Royal, but because of the hype over Battle Royal game modes in the mid 2010's they decided, "hey if we take the other game mode away then they'll just gravitate to the game mode we want them to play and we'll be as rich as the other game company's that are capitalizing on Battle Royal game modes". So lets keep game servers open and try to fund them in a dying game with an overrated game mode instead of listening to the majority of the player base that was willing to throw money at you to build, maintain, and expand on a game mode we actually want to play, lets just ignore that with brute arrogance and try to force people in the direction they no longer want to go in because of your own delusional dream of being a top dog Battle Royal game and just kill of your player base entirely and not even offer us the ability to keep playing (Just Survive) even with our own dedicated servers at the very least is just laughable and frustrating and honestly sad. I can still play call of duty games from 2008-2012 even though the (Official) servers are down we can still take control and play our own servers at the very least. It could have live on for years to come and kept players in your corner. So NO! I say DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY ON ANY DAYBREAK GAMES OF ANY KIND AND LET THIS COMPANY DIE WITH OUT DIGNITY FOR THEY HAVE NO RESPECT FOR THE PEOPLE THAT MADE THEM A SUCCESSFUL COMPANY IN THE FIRST PLACE! Players come first or you have no reason to be making games at all, cause there is no game without players.

Im really late in doing this. But I finally have to do it. Its been personal. For years now.

While H1Z1 was once the powerhorse of Zombie Survival (DayZ Mod was outdated and the standalone still garbage), with a really good map, nice balancing, a great community, and innovative ideas, Z1 is a game noone ever really needed. lets face it: pubg did it better from the beginning and COD took it to another level. Its never been an outstanding Battle Royal like H1Z1 has been as a Survival Game. But apperently, u can make way more money with a Battle Royal Shooter! Or at least the devs thought this way. First riding the upcoming survival wave, then, jumping right to the next wave to take on the next trend, Battle Royal. The first Battle Royal Game Mode was pretty okay. That was it. Me and my squad would do a round or two after getting killed in the MAIN game, just to return there right after. And you know what? H1Z1 was great. I loved it. My Squad loved it. It was hella fun. It wasnt perfect, but it could have been near perfection with ongoing work from the devs. 
And Im still pissed it had to die for this. They could have made two games. But no. One gamemode had to die apprerently. And it was the wrong one. 
Some say: "Dont cry because its over, smile because it happened." I neither cry nor smile. Im angry. Angry whenever I see this "game" in my Library and what the Devs did to the community.

This game used to be very fun, but developers need to revive this game. At the prime time of this game i played it for 8 hours a day but now i have just memories. The best gamig memories of all time. Gaming mechanic in this game is awesome.

"A Battle Royale Experience with Ups and Downs"

Z1 Battle Royale, formerly known as H1Z1, offers a mixed bag of emotions for fans of the battle royale genre. Developed by Daybreak Game Company, the game has undergone various changes and updates over the years, resulting in an experience that is both exhilarating and frustrating.

The core gameplay of Z1 Battle Royale is undeniably intense and action-packed. The fast-paced matches keep you on the edge of your seat as you compete against other players in a fight for survival. The adrenaline rush from landing in the map, quickly scavenging for weapons, and engaging in intense firefights is undeniable, making each match an adrenaline-pumping experience.

The game's map design is vast and diverse, with urban areas, forests, and rural landscapes providing different challenges and strategies. This variety ensures that no two matches feel the same, and it keeps the gameplay fresh and engaging.

Furthermore, the gunplay is solid, and the shooting mechanics are satisfying. Players who are quick on their feet and possess good aiming skills will find themselves at an advantage, making each kill feel like a well-earned victory.

However, despite these strengths, Z1 Battle Royale does have some notable drawbacks. The game has struggled with optimization issues, resulting in occasional frame rate drops and lag spikes, particularly during intense moments or when multiple players are nearby. These performance problems can be frustrating and can negatively impact the overall enjoyment of the game.

Additionally, the game's community can be somewhat toxic, with instances of cheating and unsportsmanlike behavior affecting the overall experience. While the developers have taken steps to address these issues, they still persist to some extent.

Another aspect that divides the player base is the game's overall direction. With the changing development focus and updates over time, some players may prefer the older versions of the game, leading to mixed feelings about the current state of Z1 Battle Royale.

In conclusion, Z1 Battle Royale delivers a thrilling battle royale experience with fast-paced gameplay and intense firefights. However, the game's performance issues and the presence of cheaters detract from the overall enjoyment. If you're a fan of the genre and can overlook some of the game's flaws, Z1 Battle Royale still offers moments of excitement and fun. However, for those seeking a more polished and stable battle royale experience, it may be worth considering other options in the genre.

[h1] Quick Thoughts [/h1] 
It's free, try it if you want, but this games time has long past. I had fun with it at it's peak, the survival side as well. It's been a long time since I've played it, and due to having no players i feel like what i say can't do it much justice either.

        [td]GameplayüéÆ[/td]

[/table]

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
It's the BR that started it all for a lot of people, it's where i started. I actually have well over 200 hours in this game but due the game splitting from it's survival counterpart, those hours where no longer tracked. You parachute into a map, search for gear and fight it out while the circle closes in, familiar right? Keep in mind, i had to search for games on the NA server, being from Aus i had roughly 170ms, i found roughly 7 players per game, which you know, if you like quick matches i suppose. Fortunately, the circle does compensate for the amount of players, so they are just firefights as soon as you hit the ground but with ping that high it's just not enjoyable. Their are customisation options for your character, and a store to buy cosmetics from, which, these day's, wouldn't be worth it. 

[h1] Story [/h1]
To my knowledge, their isn't one, unless there is lore outside of the game that i am not aware of.

[h1] Difficulty [/h1] 
It can be hard if you are unfamiliar to these sort of games, it might be quite jarring to come back after playing pubg, fortnite as well, or you just happen to have 200ms like myself.

[h1] Length [/h1] 
I loaded this game up, for the first time after it split and played it for about 10 minutes. No OCE or, SEA servers really limit the time i would want to spend on it, which to be fair, no point them having those as options where the player base essentially gone.

[h1] Visuals [/h1] 
It's generic, i don't really have much to say about it these days, it's not bad, not great. It always fit perfectly in that "anyone can play it" category, without looking awful.

[h1] Audio [/h1]
It's all just "fine" to my ears, music is dramatic and tense, guns audio sounds fine, footsteps are loud, but that's for game-play effect.  

[h1] Performance [/h1]
Today, you could run this game on just about every system, i'm sure, no bugs that i had come across, and if their was with how long it's been around for, then that's an issue.

[h1] Score: 5/10 [/h1]

As much as it pains me to say this, I can't recommend Z1 Battle Royale anymore. It's a dead game, Jim. But let me tell you, back in the day, it was the original Battle Royale, and it had me on the edge of my seat. It was a game that required strategy, cunning, and an itchy trigger finger to survive. But now, the lobbies are empty, and the game feels like a ghost town. It's a shame, really. But if you're looking for a taste of history, then it's worth a shot. Just don't expect much, and don't say I didn't warn you. 7/10 for the memories.

Z1 Battle Royale is a battle royale game that is marred by several technical issues and subpar gameplay mechanics. One of the biggest issues with the game is its performance, as it suffers from frequent lag and stuttering that can greatly affect the player's experience. This can be especially frustrating when playing in high-pressure situations, such as during the final stages of a match.

Another problem with Z1 Battle Royale is its unbalanced and lackluster weapons and equipment. Many of the weapons feel underpowered or unresponsive, making them difficult to use effectively in battle. Additionally, the equipment and perks system is underdeveloped, with few interesting or unique options to choose from.

Finally, the game's map design is also a drawback, as it is poorly optimized and lacks the level of detail and variety found in other battle royale games. This can make the matches feel repetitive and uninteresting after a short time.

Overall, Z1 Battle Royale is a game that falls short in several key areas, and fails to deliver a truly engaging and enjoyable battle royale experience. While it may have some redeeming features, such as its fast-paced and action-packed gameplay, these are outweighed by its technical issues and lackluster design elements.

The more I play this game the more it pisses me off. It seems like 80% of the "kids"  on this game are using some sort of assistance in being this "good?" at this game. I have played many fps games in my many years of being on a computer. Not only that but they have this concept of running their mouths with no physical threat to themselves. It doesn't matter if they die by your hands or someone else you, they feel the need to set their own mind at ease by talking shit about how good they are or how bad you are regardless who kills who. This game is more broke than the egos of all the salty, idiots that play this game. No wonder playerunknown left this compay and went off and made the game the way it should have been made. Shotguns are horrid and so are the rifles. The hit boxes seem to be huge for those that have figure out a way to hit you from a mile away yet smaller than a gnats ass for us 20%. I know for a fact that skill and better computers don't make a difference. Nor does havin' a fast monitor with high refresh rate and a 1ms delay. The number of players on this game have dropped so much and for reason. Leaving those who still have hope for this game, along with the ones that some how can shoot you without even looking at you. I may update this at some point but as far as the game, I give it a 3. I'd give it a midrange 5 but the number of kids, teenagers, and some adults that need theit mouths sewn shut after after you bust their lip and their jaw in four places, kind of drops it even more.

Will never forget the pureness of the original game. the simplistic design and rawness. Truly the 1st and greatest battle royale. Utter shame the first ever map was taken way for the big update. I would pay ¬£50 just for the re-release of the original game. with the bugs included. 

Will forever go down as one of my favourite games. Shame it all went too far.

For the developers... damn you fucked that up pretty hard but hey you had a good run and should be proud for the BR community you help build..

Bought the original game back in 2015 when it first came out. Loved it. It was a raw game with very basic elements but something about it kept you wanting more. However as time went out, so did the players. Better games came out and players ended up abandoning this game, but only after the developers abandoned this game and left it to rot. After years of not playing it. I found out Just Survive (the better part of this game) is no longer playable. And because I have more than 2 hours and obviously more than 2 weeks since I bought the game. They wont issue me a refund. It's hard to believe that a studio is so grungy about their money. I can never play this game again and yet they refuse to issue me a refund based off some 2 hour nonsense. I used to love this game, now nothing but hatred. The battle royale was good for a time being, but quickly got turned into a mobile game but for your PC. The whole studio is garbage and scumbags. Never get this game, waste of your money and time.
No one plays anymore.

Could have been one of the best zombie survival games. Purchased H1Z1 on day 1. (Jan 15, 2015) King of the kill (KotK) was originally a side game mode (that PlayerUnknown helped develop for SOE) and could only be played with event tickets that dropped in the main game. Then the BR craze happened.

Sony sold SOE, Daybreak formed.
KOTK was the money cow, and the main game became the red headed step child. 
Daybreak split H1Z1 into two games, H1Z1 Just survive and H1Z1 KOTK. 
Daybreak renames the two games, by removing H1Z1 from Just Survive and Changing H1Z1 KotK to H1Z1. 
H1Z1 is made F2P
Daybreak kills Just Survive
Daybreak basically kills H1Z1
H1Z1 is rebranded as Z1 BattleRoyal and reverted to a more favorable build of the game from 2017 to start again.

For having over 3k hours on this game i can say it was fun. But we all know what happened to a once great game. like many others i could not wait to get home to play. every day after work i looked forward to hopping on and playing for hours having a blast. even hoped to end up in the same lobby as one of my favorite streamers and just the joy and energy the community had. but sadly the dev team pushed out updates that were not needed but only little tweeks not full overhuals but they did. i still remember grasping for hope and really feeling sad that my favorite game was dying. the last straw for me was the update to the world that added working camp fires that put out smoke and made a sound. i know more than that was added but after seeing that in the game and having stuff still broken i just lost it. i still played the game and still do even though its not fun playing against the same two or three ppl that still play the game and to never really expriance the full map anymore its just sad and i really hope the game comes back one day but its not looking good. but thank you for the fun times and i will always miss Big T saying "Wake up B***! its time for another h1z1 video!" or something like that before yt became all PC but the good ole days will forever live in my memories and the memories of all the lucky players who had the pleasure of playing this once great game. and sorry for many grammar and spelling errors but i hope you get the point lol.

Honestly was my favorite BR game back in time. 
But well, the developers destroyed this game with their not smart decisions.
1. While H1Z1 was around and before PUBG was released what did Daybreak (the devs) do?
-Push out little updates every 4-6 months, such updates that were NOT worthy of the time they took to come out.
2. After PUBG and Fortnite appear what did Daybreak do?
-Push out big updates (cosmetic ones) and completely reworking both gun mechanics and vehicle mechanics (which only needed some corrections not reworks).
-Couple months later, the unoptimized, cosmetic filled, money grabbing H1Z1 is announced to go out of early access, aiming at a very good perspective for the future of the game, (which didn't work as devs expected). 
Updates that didn't bring anything good ruined this game.
It was a great battleroyale game with a lot of potential.
I wish it had never died.
I still have hope that this game will become popular again.

I've been playing H1Z1 since the original Z1 back in 2016. Yes, this game has had its issues with bugs, unnecessary updates, and other major things. But the amount of fun I have had playing this game and memories I have made playing with friends will always be there. It hurts to see that this game went from being one of the Top Battle Royale Games of a player base of 150,000 to what it is now. I know that Day Break pushed out updates to help improve the game but failed to realize that most things they did were completely unnecessary and also failed to listen to the community's feedback, especially after the Combat Update. Back in early 2019, when Jace Hall & NantG took over H1 and began to make bug fixes, improve the games play style in regards to combat, movement, etc. There was hope for this game once again. But it was too good to be true, and once it was announced that NantG would hand back the game to Day Break, I feel as if all faith for H1 was lost through out the whole community. 

Its still sad to this day to see how this game died because of the amount of potential it had. But in regards to that, H1Z1 will always remain as one of my top favorite game!

Maybe back in 2017 or earlier this game was great, but now in 2021, don't even think about downloading this game. I purchased it back in 2017, but the game is free now so you don't have to think about spending money at least.

Anyway not much to be said here, it's an online game and you need people to play with or against. Servers are dead, with players up to 30 max on each server, whereas it used to stretch to 200 players in one session. These people are also the veterans of this game and won't have any mercy on you, so if you are a new comer, you will have a terrible time unfortunately.

The game runs well on medium to high settings on a mid-range system. The coolest thing about this game is that you can toggle your view-distance, so you can set it higher whilst you are in a game to see far when you need to and when you don't you can set it lower for that maximum fps boost.

At this time there is much better BR games to pick up (Apex Legends).

The only marginally interesting or entertaining part of this game is it's history.

January 15, 2015: It's sold under the name of H1Z1. It was marketed as an open world zombie survival game, akin to DayZ. I bought it for 20$. The game does not run.

After a time, they release a new gamemode; King of the Kill. It's a battle royale mode, made specifically because PLAYERUNKNOWN made a hugely successful battle royale mod for the game but then split off to make his own game (PUBG).

February 5, 2016: KOTK is doing well, so they split it off from the game, both of them costing 20$. They silently abandon the original game, only doing small feature updates and adding nothing but bugs. H1Z1 (The survival game.) is renamed to H1Z1 Just Survive. KOTK is renamed H1Z1: King of the Kill. Not long after they rename H1Z1 Just Survive to simply Just Survive (Which sounds like a terrible 3$ app game.) and rename H1Z1 King of the Kill to just H1Z1. (H1Z1 Battle Royale on consoles.) Development of the original survival game, "Just Survive", is still mostly halted.

October 24, 2018: Just Survive, the survival game i paid for, is shut down. The game is removed from my, and everyone else's steam library, with no refund. KOTK, or H1Z1, or H1Z1 Battle Royale...or...whatever the crap they named it, is shut down as well, and re-published and renamed as a different game, Z1 Battle Royale, obviously done to alienate the game from it's wretched history.

The kicker? It's free. Also, it's still called H1Z1 Battle Royale on consoles, and when Z1 BR is run, the window is named H1Z1.

They made a game said it was like DayZ. It didn't even work. Then they simply deleted it from my library with no refund. Z1 BR is dead, it garners about 3 active players. They actually, legitimately built a fake game and then deleted it for money.

Utterly disgusting development team. When everyone said the original game was going down in flames due to terrible updates, horrible balancing fix attempts that only worsened the balance, and endless amounts of bugs spilling into the game, i sat there, with hope. This is what i got.

They said the original H1Z1 was originally going to be made free. I was fine, 20$ for instant beta access to a DayZ game was fine. What they didn't say is that it was a blatant lie and they would toss the game in the trash in favor of another random game they made using the original games assets (I told you. They're terrible. Too lazy to even make new assets.) simply because Fortnite was getting popular.

And after all that?

The game sucks balls.

Don't buy download this game.

this game used to be the greatest game in the world at one point, unfortunately it will never see a day like that again. this game changed my life, my friends life, and many others life. if only the devs did not try and copy every other game it would have stayed amazing. sucks that this newer generation will never be able to join a full h1z1 lobby with a bunch of people blasting music, hearing a Chinese person screaming "china number 1", or a random guy cursing around the helicopter. i pray one day that this game gets revived, because if it does, I will sure as hell be there.

Survival H1Z1 is the reason I bought my first early access title, and the reason I will never buy into early access again.

I paid for a open world zombie survival game, with open mics and proximity chat that felt more like the walking dead than any walking dead video game to date. The world truly felt like playing the walking dead as I could hear other players talking to each other as they got closer and the people where the real threat not the zombies. So tense, so good! What I ended up with was a mediocre micro-transaction filled battle royale game!

The games strong point was the survival game play not its gun play and they killed that part to chase an upcoming trend and only fall flat on their face when games that are better at shooting showed up. Now we have a dead survival game and piss poor br game to show for our early support of this dev! I feel duped, burned, tricked, and conned

This bait and switch has forever burned me on the idea of early access. Thanks a lot H1Z1, and may this cautionary tale serve as a warning to others. DO NOT fund a game in early access, never a buy a product before its finished and ready for sale. You'll only walk away with disappointment. That rule apply to every product, not just video games.

Good times, but those times are gone and the devs never even tried to fix it, the only resurgence I saw in this game was when they added the car battle royale mode, that was a new idea and it did breath some life back into the game for a little while, but even that has faded now

I honestly miss some of the old features of this game. Everything that was pre-season 3 was amazing, and the game was great. But, I do not mind having multiple options in a game. I love having multiple game mode types in one game to change things up. There are a ton of people who want preseason 3 H1Z1 back. Like bring back that game and call it H1Z1 classic or something. I mean there are definitely positives in the newer version of the game. But I feel like there should be more of pre-season 3. I mean I honestly feel like you catered a game just for China. 

I even feel like the shading in pre-season 3 was better. I felt there was better visibility in that version.
Forced shadows shouldn't be on, we should be able to turn them off. 
The battle royale experience is awful in the new game. 
There were more refined spawns in preseason 3. You didn't always spawn in the mountains or at the edge of the map all the time. 
The gas has changed. Like if you are caught in the gas you are dead. Never used to be like that. I remember having more time to loot and and get gear and plan my next route to the safe zone. I like that the gas moved at a slower speed, and even the timer for the gas gave you more ample to time. On the contrary though you still had to make haste when looting. But you didn't have to settle for junk rushing around aimlessly when you could have more time to find gear, calculate, plan and coordinate your next move to the safe zone.

H1Z1 is a thriving game which sports some of the best open mics of any game. In my experience playing this game, not a single person has ever said anything mean to me like "kys, dye of cancer, you are trash". If you play this game, your opponents and even squad mates will lift you up, elevate, and empower you to become the perfect gamer. In addition, this game sports an active and engaging developer group which constantly make backwards updates before completely changing the shooting and movement completely. This is followed by reverting it and releasing more crates. I can't praise this game enough.

Introduction: Before I start, I have 760 hours on H1Z1 and started playing right at the end of preseason 2, and I have reached Royalty in a few of those seasons. I have a good understanding of the game and it's mechanics. i've watched this game "evolve" over the various preseasons, whether it evolved for the good or the bad is really up to the player. With that being said, the majority of the people who have been playing for a good while like me, agree that H1Z1 really has taken a turn for the worst. Before you start to blame the new players for wanting the game to be easier for them or the advanced players for wanting some sort of change in gameplay mechanics, none of their opinions really mattered in the first place, let me explain why. Daybreak Games is the one to blame for this game's downfall, not the players or community, the devs. They didn't change the game because of the new players who wanted the game to be easier because they kept getting 2 tapped by the good people. The devs want more money, period. Honestly, I'm having trouble typing that with confidence just because the game is now dying because of their poor decisions to cater to brand new players rather than enforcing a "skill gap". They're digging themselves a hole and it might be too late to update the game out of the bottom of it.


Gameplay Mechanics: My biggest point to make about mechanics has to be the recoil. The combat update ruined this game and I cannot force that statement enough. The new AR-15 recoil especially made spraying WORSE and all it did was lower the skill gap. Daybreak should have reliazed that horizontal recoil was completely unique to H1. Seriously, what other game can implement something as dumb as horizontal recoil and have the game do good? The answer is no other game besides H1Z1. It was the most fun and unique aspect to the game which oddly made sense while you were playing. Switching to vertical recoil was just taking away the uniqueness of the game and just turning it into a shitty mainstream game. Next, the movement. If you have ever played PUBG, you know how it feels when you move compared to pre-combat update H1Z1. It feels slow and sluggish, which is exactly what post combat update H1 feels like. The pattern is starting to form, Daybreak is making H1Z1 as close to PUBG as possible. This really sucks to see for the veteran players because we play this game because its NOT PUBG. This review is already long so I'll leave it with those 2 main points.



Unneccesary Changes: Daybreak is known to ignore big issues within the game while spending their time on trivial things to add to the game that nobody cares about. Examples, in the most recent update, new gun models were added. Someone explain to me why we needed that? Anyways, some more examples I won't go in detail with are new crates, new POIs, a new menu, I could go on but you get the point.


Unqualified Developers: I want to know what college or university these people attended, or better yet if they even finished high school. Some of the things these people do are so beyond retarded I physically can't even comprehend the reasoning behind it. An example is in the combat training or deathmatch mode, who's idea was it to have a set loadout that cannot be changed by the player, (i.e. AR/AK, shotty/smh, pistol) just let us make our own loadouts with our preferred weapons in whatever slot we're comfortable with. It seems like whenever the community asks for something, Daybreak does the polar opposite. We asked for better hitreg, a better shotgun spread/damage, and the reversal or fix to desync. What did we get? The fucking combat update. 


I think I'll stop there, if you want more info just go on the H1 reddit, there are tons of great informative people on there. If you read my review all the way through, you're a beast. If you found it informative, a thumbs up would be much appreciated. There are definitly points I missed in this review, so if I catch any I'll be sure to make an edit at a later time. My final verdict is I can't reccomend you this game in it's current state. Thanks for reading.

This game died because Arc Legger and his team were the misfits from Sony before they booted them out with their Planetside copy. That said, the game was somehow still incredible despite the incompetent dev team for at least a year after the BR mode was released. The blood splats and different functions of motorcycle vs. tactical helmets made the game challenging and unique. It was the most fun BR to date, bar none. Unfortunately, about a year and a half in, Arclegger spent more time fanboying Lirik on Twitch than listening to his player base and completely overhauled the camera view, removed the blood splat mechanic and replaced it with basic B**** hit markers, then he made all helmets the exact same. As if his player base hadn't suffered enough, he and his team of dropouts thought it would be a great idea to completely take the map everyone knew and loved out of the game forever, replacing it with a neon-colored, vomit-inducing map straight out of Banjo Kazooey. I have never seen a player base collectively quit a game so quickly in my life. Seriously folks, this game had the most robust and die-hard player base in the gaming industry at the time and it disappeared overnight while Arclegger counted his shekels and sent his resume to his local Subway. This game died the day those hackers forced the CEO of Sony's video game division to land his private jet and cut Arclegger loose with a great game so he could ruin it. I'm not even joking, this dude named his company "Daybreak Games".... "TheyBreak Games", you can't make this sh** up!

Previously, there was a wonderful project called H1Z1, after changing the developer, the game was divided and turned out-H1Z1: Just Survive and H1Z1: King of the kill, then removed from the names "H1Z1", and even later the last project was renamed Z1BattleRoyale. If H1Z1: Just Survive was doomed to fail immediately, then H1Z1: King of the kill still kicked for a while. Back in the heyday of the Battle Royale genre, there were disputes about which was better - PUB or H1Z1: King of the kill, although even then everything was extremely obvious. This game was saved only by more adequate optimization than its competitor, so buckets could play this new and fashionable BattleRoyale of yours. The game itself is a crooked craft of the genre of royal battles and has:
- Poor variety of content.
- Bad shooting.
- Stable monotony.
- Weak online.
- Poor gameplay.
- Bright "parrot" clothes.
This game is terrible in every way, in 2021 there is absolutely no point in returning to the project.

Z1BR started as H1Z1 and was back then the best survival game on the market. Then they split the game into two different games and then its starting to go down hill, and after some time they stopped focus on the survival game and only made improvement for there battle royal. Now today Z1 battle royal has lost must of it core base and the game is more or less empty. 

Pros
- Short matches 
- Simplified battle royal

Cons
- Multiplayer near abandoned
- Few weapon with zero customization
- Microtransaction

[h1]     [/h1]


[u] 2nd Review  [/u]

Posted: 13 March 2018, 7 months after the last one.
I'm updating it because of the game going free-to-play and out of Early Access.


[h1] Backstory: [/h1]

I bought this game for ‚Ç¨19.99 in [b] January 27, 2017( Pre-Season 3) [/b] and I currently have [b] 1011 hrs. [/b] So I'm a "trustworthy" reviewer and I'm not BIASED. H1Z1 is my first ever PC game as I was previously an Xbox gamer. The reason I went all the way to buy a $2000 PC 
(First PC btw) was so I could play with all my friends and H1Z1 was the $HIT back then :)

[h1] Okay, let's start with the review. [/h1]

[b] Is this game good? [/b] 

I think so. 

This game has definitely come a long way and improved internally, unfortunately, it has lost a lot of its player base. When I did my review 7 months ago it peaked at 140.000 players, now it's 41.000 and only because it went F2P. Right before that, it was 8.000. I hope this game will survive.. It's really apart of me by now. The reason the game was dying... Well, Daybreak did their biggest mistake ever, releasing [url=https://www.h1z1.com/update-notes/combat-update-live-patch-notes-August-2017] the Combat Update  [/url] and long story short. It ruined the game and what made it H1Z1, but now it's back to its glory IMO.

[b]So? Should you download and play this game?[/b]
Why not? It's free :) Nah, seriously you should. If you can handle getting killed a lot in the beginning, rage and frustration then absolutely. H1Z1 IS VERY FUN when you win games, kill other players etc. Anyways let's start with the cons and pros. 

Cons: Desync, the shotgun currently and the toxic player base.

Pros: Great gun mechanics, very skill, fast pace, amazing driving mechanics, third/first person and it's very rewarding mentally. 

[b]Final verdict.[/b]

8/10
Do I recommend it? 
Yes, I do.

Hope to see you in Fort Destiny :) 

h1] Header text    [/h1]

[u] 1st Review [/u]

 Posted: 10 August 2017

[h1] H1Z1: King of the Kill [/h1]
 
[b]Okay so is this game good?[/b]
hmmm no not really
[b]Is it addicting?[/b]
YES
[b]Should you spend your money on this game?[/b]
It depends.. If you can handle rage and frustration sure. The game can be fun at times like when you win games, kill ppl etc. But the shotgun... oooh the shotgun is trash. Let's start off with the cons because that's the easiest one to do. 

Cons: Hit Registration, Desync, THE SHOTGUN, a lot of bugs and glitches.

Pros: Enjoyable when it works. More specific huh? well if you like third person shooters then this is your game I guess.

[b]Final verdict...[/b]

If you got the money sure but I would say wait until the combat update which is in a couple of weeks to see if daybreak doesn't mess up.

Devs should have listened to the community, if they had this game would still be alive today. 

The survival aspect of the game had a lot of charm and is something that is greatly missed. The battle royale game mode was fun at first, however, it was quickly outshone by other entries into the genre. I only wish the development team had realised this rather than doubling down on the battle royale and neglecting the survival aspect of the game.

The splitting of the two game modes into separate projects and the numerous rebrandings of said games helped solidify these games as the rotting necrotic corpses they are today.

H1Z1 was one of the first Steam games I played, and either first or second one that I fell in love with. So it was a real pity for me to witness how the game has been transformed into this fourth-rate, copy-cat, constantly glitched amalgamation of bad creative choices. But at the same time I am really proud and overjoyed by the reaction of the community, and although I think there is no realistic way that we can get the game back, I encourage everyone to voice themselves if they haven't already and write one of this stating your opinion and maybe a nice experience you had with the old game, so we can focus on the positive things even in the face on this loss we have all suffered. And who knows, maybe one day the developers will realise the atrocities they committed. 
I'll leave you with a quote that I think really describes the oblivion of unshameful-ness/ delusion the devs have wrapped themselves with. (From the game blurb found above)
"Staying true to its "King of the Kill" roots, the game has been revamped and restored to the classic feel, look, and gameplay everyone fell in love with. Play solo, duos, or fives and be the last ones standing."
...
To the devs, go fuck yourselves.
To all of you, my fellow comrades, keep true to yourselves (because I think that is what we can take away from this experience) and don't forget to spread the love and be supportive and amicable with each other.
Farewell,

After two years of this game being out, the shotgun is still never fixed despite all of the "fixes" they implement. 

This game would actually be good and fun to play if it wasn't for hit registration and car physics being fucked up all over the place. The concept is good, the map is playable-ish.

If daybreak actually listened to customer feedback and acted upon it, they would immediately fix hit registration on the shotgun and the AR15 bullets.

A good order to follow would be like so:
1)Fix all shotguns. Completely scrape the code and model for the current shotgun, and make a new model and re-script the code with those "high-level developers".
2) Next fix all of the missing AR15 and AK47 shots. Headshots SHOULD ALWAYS be on the head and deal damage, and bullets should NEVER just disappear out of nowhere. 
3) Desync: Oh for the love of god, please fix your damn desync issues. This fucks over so many people it is actually unreal and funny to watch on twitch highlights. Instead of allowing the server to adjust itsself based on each individual player, make one rate that the server refreshes to. If a player's internet can't keep up, then boo hoo, they lag(not like that's already a huge issue with the game).
4) Car Physics: Oh for the love of god this too. I'm not talking about when people drive off cliffs and their cars' explode. I'm talking about when a car gets stuck inbetween a fire hydrant and a pole, and magically their car explodes. Getting your car blown up by a fucking wooden bench would never happen, at least not in 0.500 seconds. Also on a side note, if I run someone over with a car and it is apparent, it should kill them, not make the car glitch.
5) Map issues: There are still issues with the map(duplicate doors, clips where they shouldn't be, no clips where they should be, etc.). Noticeable ones are the roof of one of the buildings in Ranchito, where there is a complete shield around a person and they are essentially invisible. 
6) (this relates to the issue of desync) Trading: For the love of god, when playing, my first three games, I traded 3 TIMES IN A ROW. Trading should NEVER HAPPEN, especially after 2 years of "development". One person shoots the gun first that gets the kill, bullets do not wait for the other person to shoot their gun and then go.

Overall, Daybreak doesn't give a shit about their game and it will have to start declining for them to start losing money to actually give a shit about the game. They keep releasing skins(just like valve), without fixing their game, and as long as they are still making money, they won't actually put effort into fixing the game.

Jesus Christ, PUBG has saved my life because it is way more balanced than KOTK. The shotgun is just way too unreliable. The new map had me thinking that the game was going uphill, but all the same problems have not been fixed. The hit reg is stil not good at all, the glitchy car mechanics make for frustrating moments, and sometims you randomly just die for no clear reason, like you have just suffered from cardiac arrest. Sure, the ranking system is cool and Daybreak have come out with some pretty cool skins, but that is just for looks, they are not pushing out updates on the regular fixing the bad mechanics they have already. PUBG is the way to go if you want a battle royale game in my opinion, i dont think i ever want to reinstall this game onto my pc. The only things going for this game for me is that not everybody camps like in PUBG and it is more fast paced, but for all the other drawbacks, it is not enough for me to give this piece of shit failure a positive review. Thanks for reading.

Z1 Battle Royale (formerly H1Z1 and King of the Kill) is a free-to-play battle royale game developed and published by Daybreak Game Company. 
Players can choose to play solo, in a duo, or in groups of five, with the goal of being the final person or final team remaining.
H1Z1 started as a survival game in 2015 and received later a battle royale mode with the help of Brendan Green (PlayerUnknown).
In 2016 H1Z1 had been split into two separate games, subtitled Just Survive and King of the Kill (KOTK).
At its prime KOTK had an all-time peak of 151,239 concurrent players in 2017.
Then came the combat update, the gun play and recoil was drasitcally changed for its core guns and the result was that the playerbase was shrinking.
In 2018 the game was made free to play. Most players have already switched to other Battle Royale games.
In March 2019, the game was rebranded as Z1 Battle Royale under the development of NantG Mobile. The target of NantG Mobile was to revert the majority of the changes made to the game's mechanics, weapon balancing, and user interface since the "Preseason 3" era of the game in early-2017. However, NantG handed Z1 Battle Royale back to Daybreak. It was announced that Daybreak will only keep the servers running but there will be no more updates.
Over the years there were 2 different maps, Z1 and Z2. A 3rd was for PS4 only.
It was alot of fun to play the H1Z1 Battle Royale game, especially before the combat update. It was always kinda broken and had lot of glitches, but it has given it its charme. It was fun to watch streamers raging because for no reason the car they were driving explodes and so on.
Wrong decisions of its developer and other competitors on the market made the game die.
In a match there is place for 150 players but nowadays you can be happy if you find a match with 20+ players.
The Just Survivors servers have already shutted down, I think it is only a matter of time until Z1 Battle Royale will follow.
As it is free to play you can check it out, but there are more popular BR games out there, from my point of view it is no fun anymore to play with something like 10 - 20 players a round.

I recommend this game, only if I could play its original iteration of Battle Royale, and only if it could have never been separated from the survival aspects.  H1Z1 as a survival game, base builder, and all that it was; was an amazingly fun experience.  It wasn't Day Z, and it didn't have to be, it had its own charm, its own moments and interactions; like when the hospital first became a location, more fleshed out, the original map being expanded in size and scope and feeling more lived in.  It was an amazing game.  Z1 Battle Royale felt--like it was fine at first, it felt like H1Z1, the same mechanics, the same firearm feel, recoil, aiming, and then a few updates along the line and it felt like it was trying to be Fortnite.  It felt cheap.  Not unique, not the fun experience I remembered.  And then all these whacky modes start entering the scene, and even earlier on the game is separated in to two and then Just Survive as it would be known, was just killed off.  Gone.

H1Z1 from years ago, was an amazing, fun, and enjoyable game.  The survival game was excellent.  The battle royale was slower and that was -OKAY-, that was more than okay!  They shouldn't have tried to make it something it wasn't.  And I wish it could go back to the way it was.

H1Z1 was once a very popular game with a decent playerbase, but if you ask most people about it today, they will tell you that it‚Äôs just not the same as it was in the past. If you can manage to connect to a game filled with players right now ( which will be challenging), you will likely get destroyed by pros who've been playing the game since it‚Äôs peak. I will recommend this game becasue of all the fun I got out of it when I used to play. I suppose if you are very good at the game or are capable of looking past the issues this game has and enjoying it for what it is, then you may like it, but I just cannot enjoy this game now as much as I did before (It was one of my favorites). Also, just to put it out there, another common complaint about H1 is that the devs did not listen to the community when it was in early access, and that if they would‚Äôve done this they would‚Äôve had more fans.

The older versions of this game were worth your time as a gamer or as an actual buyer of the game. Originally. The old map was organic but hardcore, scrapped. The old shooting-system being completely unique, "fixed" (it just got replaced with a stock boring and very unskilled system), also scrapped. Daybreak added a new "good" map which wasn't utilized properly for most of it's used life-cycle (nobody should play this game anymore atm, seriously) and it gets worse.

There's no access to the old map, likely because it was "remade" despite ignoring the fact that they aren't similar even vaguely. The developers only focused on spewing out new colorful skins of varying rarities etc, as new competing products crept up and posed as a threat. Essentially, the game imploded on itself because the developers never understood why their game was great in the first place. If i could speak to the entire dev team, i'd be insanely furious on how they literally gored their entire game part by part, and then spent the rest of their remaining cash on sponsored streams from Twitch personalities (NO joke, summit1g for example). And they did this after making the game free2play. After butchering the game, and after people had learned the new map which barely got used past it's 50% hotspots because their designed code was so bad the end/ring couldn't reach the cool outer limits of the map.

What irks me a ton at present day is that i still to this day get no way of going back to play the old map what so ever. At best one get youtube vods of the map, it's not good enough and i would cleanly stay away from them and their products till maybe when they make a good game and manage it like adults again. It's just an idea though.

horrid

I really don't know where to start with this review, it genuinely is sad to see the state of this game today and the key decision makers should hold their heads in shame.
I have over 400hrs on H1, played since the beginning and it's fair to say the experience has nosedived with the arrival of each patch. There have always been flaws but these were easy to overlook in the early days(especially as it was an 'Early Release' game), the arcadey gameplay was addictively fun which made it a great alternative to PUBG. The fact this game is now free and still nobody wishes to play speaks volumes, it's almost impossible to find a game with more than 10 players.

The main reasons why this game went down the toilet:
‚Ä¢ Gunplay - Weapon balance was constantly being changed, i lost count of the amount of times the effective range, spread and damage of the shotgun was altered. As a player it gets very tiring very quickly to keep up with incessant and unnecessary tinkering. 

‚Ä¢ Physics overhauls - Yep, something as simple as the way your player runs, jumps and interacts with the environment has seen multiple iterations as well. When something isn't broken in the first place and fans aren't complaining about, don't try fixing it. Vehicle physics were always a huge talking point among players and streamers yet very little has ever been done to sort them.

‚Ä¢ Hunger for Money - I understand that a business needs to make money but... way too much emphasis was put on crates and skins from an early stage. It felt like this area of the game received more attention than anything else. 

I really hope Daybreak read these reviews, the only positives ones i have seen are from questionable accounts with 1-2 hrs under their belt. Your genuine playerbase is disappointed at how their investment was so poorly managed.

[b]H1Z1[/b]

A game that seems to have been around so long, it would be in a nursing home and still not collecting social security. What I mean by this is that it has changed so much and went through at least two world wars and it's still alive. Unsurprisingly it got quite a few bullet holes in the form of poor decisions by the developers. I watched the original H1Z1 that I loved go from great to satisfactory to sub-par to broken and back to satisfactory. While it had it's glory days, it seems the developers want to take it back to the wild west days when it wasn't dumbed-down to meet the popularity of similar titles. I appreciate this quite a lot since I hope it remains in a humble state not seeking to be better than it is. At the core is a special thrill, less flashy than other games, but more raw.

[b]Rating: 5.1/10[/b]

The mark of shame attached to Daybreak is bigger than the company itself. These guys have the ultimate recipe for disaster that no one managed to accomplish so far in gaming history, but them. And it's a well deserved shame. I don't know what happened when Sony became Daybreak internally, but the decisions they made with H1Z1 after were the most stupid ever. Just Survive and the Battle Royale mod were supposed to come free, yet they split the games and doubled the game price. Even if games were split on paper, you would feel they were lying, as every Battle Royale update would crash the Just Survive game as well. They used Just Survive as a cash cow and most of us were fine with it if they would just fix some old fkn bugs and deal more with cheaters. All we asked for. Instead their updates would be more cashing oriented and bringing more bugs, making the early version of Just Survive (while company name was still Sony) looking like a perfect release. And as if that wasn't enough, they decided to close the game, after they milked they shit out of it. And I called it, way before it happened. Give us back the early stages of the early access H1Z1, the survival game. There will be some redemption in that.

This game started as H1Z1, the best zombie survival game on the market at the time. Their battle royal mode that came along with it was great too, however they saw a boom due to it on twitch and got greedy. They stopped development for their zombie survival game and focused on nothing but the battle royal experience. Once PUBG got big they got nervous and made changes to turn it into a PUBG clone. This failed and the game has never been the same since. They took away an amazing zombie survival experience, a fun and competitive battle royal mode. This was all for nothing. You cant play H1Z1 any more and Z1 battle royal lost its identity and was thrown in the trash. Reminds me of the poor choices the culling dev team made to kill their game. All of this for nothing.
So where is my refund?

I purchased the game far before the game even split into two and this BR version turning free.

I stuck with the PVE side of the game because my PC at the time handles this game very poorly and competitive play was just impossible. But now it's been very long and Just Survive has closed down.

Now that I can play it and seeing the game's player base went up during January 2020 (10,000 active)
I was curious and tried it out.

Found out that they locked the Asia server and made it so when you have 200 ping above you won't be able to do any sort of combat. So that's why the players didn't stay long and immediately went down to barely 1000 active during Feb and March 2020.

I don't think this game will ever be alive again if it stayed in it's current course, especially locking an entire region. How is it even going to be possible to play the game at decent ping when your proper region is gone?
Can't believe I rooted for this game before.

H1Z1...

What do I have to say. The community was thrash, everyone hated each other. Sometimes you get a earrape when you killed someone. But that is a part of the game and I can laugh about it.

The first time when you play you just want to survive and win the game. And that feeling is so great if you win the first game. But after some wins you are grinding for the kills and then win the game. Everytime when you set a record for yourself your day can't go wrong.
The feeling is legit legendary.

Sadly there were some bugs that the developers did not fixed. And the updates were not good most of the time. When the game Fortnite and PUBG came out, this game died. The skin prices dropped and probably a lot of people lost a lot of money. Also I did, but for me it was worth the feelings I had with this game.

The best time was when I played a lot of games with my friend Justin and we dropped a thirty kill game win. Legendary!

One of the worst stories of developers destroying their own game since Flagship studios. H1Z1 was an awesome zombie survival game that really helped to set the tone for these survival sandbox games. back then the Battle Royal was a side game and it too was amazing. then PUBG happened and Daybreak decided they wanted to cash in. They split the game into this and Just Survive. Then they said "Fuck Just Survive were going to milk this battle ground thing". Howd that work out Daybreak?

No idea of recent changes but the shear amount of mistake devs made along the way made a game that was one of my favorite of all time die a painfully slow death. The head scratching idea and lack of changes to them and lack of addressing main concerns of players made them lose everyone. I miss the alpha days and early new z2 map days. The gun intial bullet drop change was nice but the second time they changed it they should of just slapped a cod symbol on the title and said it was the same game.

Best battle royale available since day 1 imo. Before fortnite & pubg there was this; lead developer from pubg actually helped create this masterpiece prior to the others you hear about frequently.

Very balanced gameplay requires good instincts, tactics, and aim. 3rd person is kinda universal for this game and it has an arcade like feel which helps the game overall---without taking anything from its realism in terms of last man standing.

Balanced in terms of weapon choice. Theres not a huge variety and no attachments which add a lot of balance and keep you focused on the gameplay instead of hording items---big plus in my book.

If you like battle royale games and havent given z1br a try then it is a must imo. Dont get discouraged at first you will improve most by being aggressive and going after frags--the name of the game is king of the kill at least that was the original gametype back in 2015-16 when h1z1 came out :)

n between the very start of an H1Z1 match ‚Äì in which up to 150 people parachute down onto a small and continually shrinking map ‚Äì and the final moments laced with exploding crossbow bolts, it‚Äôs utter chaos. Sometimes that‚Äôs the good kind that leads to great moments of action, and sometimes it‚Äôs the disorganized and directionless kind that leads to boredom. In a genre now dominated by Fortnite and PlayerUnknown‚Äôs Battlegrounds, this battle royale struggles to find its own identity despite predating both ‚Äì with the most promising spark of inspiration coming from an inventive new destruction derby-style mode.

H1Z1 is actually a refreshingly simple game in a lot of ways when all is said and done. Where contemporaries PUBG and Fortnite define themselves by aiming for a realistic feel and zany base-building shenanigans, respectively, H1Z1 floats somewhere in the middle. You can‚Äôt attach scopes and quick-draw magazines to your rifles and there are no sky bases or mile-high sniper towers to be found in this one. That lack of commitment to a signature look and style often leaves an empty feeling, even if it does have the benefit of being a more accessible battle royale as a result.

Share
Autoplay setting: On
H1Z1 tries to fill that void with fast-paced action, but isn‚Äôt entirely successful. For example, at the very start of each match teams pick which region of the map to drop down to, and as areas become more populated they‚Äôll start to glow yellow, orange, and eventually red, giving you the ability to determine how much of a firefight you want to immediately land in. (In PUBG, by contrast, the plane‚Äôs path and the circle‚Äôs placement is random, and you only get to pick when you drop.) Picking where to go makes the drop feel more strategic, but removes a lot of the impromptu strategy involved with random drop spots, and that makes them feel more routine. Most teams end up picking the same handful of popular spots regardless of the safe zone and just drive to the zone once they find a vehicle.
Wait, Which H1Z1 Is This?
Originally, H1Z1 debuted on Steam Early Access in 2015 as a hardcore zombie survival game inspired directly by the popular ARMA 2 mod, DayZ. A few months later it added a tense battle royale multiplayer mode known as King of the Kill
SEE DEAL
, which proved so popular it was spun out into its own separate Early Access game. In February 2016, the original zombie-focused H1Z1 was renamed as Just Survive, and in August 2017, King of the Kill was renamed back to H1Z1, and finally launched out of early access on February 28, 2018. That‚Äôs what‚Äôs reviewed here.
Once on the ground, in my experience, a match of H1Z1 consists of three phases. The first all about looting and getting to the circle, if you aren‚Äôt already in it. The circle in H1Z1 shrinks slowly over the course of the match, just as you‚Äôd expect, except here the threat you‚Äôre avoiding is depicted as deadly poisonous gas instead of an electric force field.
Since the entirety of H1Z1‚Äôs design is predicated off of ramping up the action, the looting of the countryside is greatly compressed relative to most battle royale games. The good news is that there‚Äôs never a dull start ‚Äì during my time with H1Z1 I‚Äôve rarely needed to check more than two or three houses before I had all three weapon slots filled, a helmet, a backpack, and a thrown item like a grenade or molotov cocktail. That‚Äôs enough to carry me to the end game when the crates of really good stuff start to fall. The bad news is that there‚Äôs little variety: even though the locations of the houses I loot may change, the loot cycle always stays the same.
The good news is there‚Äôs never a dull start.
‚Äú
The one extra layer to the typical looting phase that H1Z1 introduces is some light crafting elements. You won‚Äôt be building an entire base like in Fortnite, but you can break down basic items like shirts and backpacks into pieces of cloth that can be turned into bandages for healing, or combined with duct tape and sheets of metal for body armor. It‚Äôs a shallow idea that never evolves into a full crafting system like the one found in Just Survive (H1Z1‚Äôs spin-off sibling) and could have honestly been left out with little consequence.

Grabbing more ammo never hurts, but there aren‚Äôt any attachments to search for or ultra-special weapons of any kind to stumble upon. Most people roll with an AR-15 as their ranged primary weapon, an AK-47 as their mid-range automatic weapon, and either a recurve bow with explosive arrows (if they‚Äôre lucky) or a shotgun for up-close blasting. Since I always ended up using the same few weapons every game, there was an utter lack of variety. Sure, I could‚Äôve switched things up by choosing other weapons, but without hope of finding attachments that could make one of the others more enticing, there‚Äôs zero incentive to do so.
Once the first round of teams are killed off, that‚Äôs when the next phase begins, and it can either be the most exciting part or the most boring. Depending on whether you‚Äôre playing solo, duo, or in five-person squads, your strategy may vary a bit, but this is the part of the match where people drive around and try to pick off as many stragglers as possible. What makes this more exciting here than other games is that it‚Äôs an area where H1Z1 embraces absurdity: you cannot run people over, but you can jump out of a vehicle at full speed without taking damage. Those two facts totally change the dynamic of facing off against a fast-approaching car in favor of the on-foot player, making it closer to a fair fight. But if you don‚Äôt evade the incoming fire from passengers and take out the driver before they close the gap they can pull up right beside you, hop out, blast you with a shotgun, then jump back in all in one fell swoop.

Depending on how much of your team is left at this point and how confident you are in your aim, this phase usually turns into either an intense bloodbath or a tedious game of hide and seek as you evade the roving bands of car-equipped marauders. For me, too often it‚Äôs been the latter, making a third of a typical H1Z1 match feel like a waste of time more often than not.
Going for crates is terrifying and risky.
‚Äú
One way or another, the objective is to get down to the last 15 or so people left, because that‚Äôs when the third phase kicks off and the good stuff starts to happen. By then, the circle is usually too small for vehicles because anyone driving around in a loud car will get shot immediately. Meanwhile, crates containing ultra-powerful rifles, snipers with scopes, and more begin to fall, creating irresistible bait that can either be looted or camped. Going for crates is terrifying and risky, but if you don‚Äôt upgrade your gear you‚Äôre at a big disadvantage in the final battle to come.
While I found myself enjoying H1Z1‚Äôs fast-paced rounds (on average they last around 15-20 minutes, as opposed to upwards of a half hour or more for PUBG), it‚Äôs a harsh place where death can come so suddenly and quickly that it risks being off-putting to new players. A surprising number of people who are playing H1Z1 right now, especially in solo, either have some of the most incredible twitch reflexes I‚Äôve ever seen or are hacking (or some combination of the two). In most matches, even with body armor and a helmet equipped, it seemed like I died far more quickly than I was used to in similar games. If you struggle at first I highly recommend playing in groups, even with random people, or trying out the Combat Zone mode to hone your skill on a map with unlimited respawns.

There‚Äôs no element of pay-to-win in play.
‚Äú
Beyond developing your skills there‚Äôs no actual progression to H1Z1 outside of pure cosmetic options, which, to its credit, means there‚Äôs no element of pay-to-win in play. Between matches you can buy cates full of skins using one of three different currencies: crowns, which you pay real money for, skulls, which you earn by completing challenges and finishing games, and scrap, which you

Why is this game so dead :(

A good, fun, simple game that is spoiled by a few people - a minority of the player base and the developers.

This game is a beautiful old house that's owners have just left to fall into disrepair and become overgrown. That doesn't stop those that know it's there, hiding behind a mass of undergrowth, from playing within it's rooms. If only it's managers cared enough to maintain it and display it to the world as the beautiful gem it could be. But alas, it seems never to be.

Devs need to listen to its players for once. We are still here and playing! And by 'players' I don't mean big streamers that dictate what should be done for their own gaming experience. Look where that got this game, and look where the streamers are now... not here, because the average players didn't like the constantly needless changing and messing with the game and so they left. No decent player base means no streamers, which means the game isn't reaching out to people.

This has resulted in a small community of regular players which I can't really complain about. Many of us are nice, but again some have to spoil it with mindless toxicity or by cheating. But even they are dropping off.

I would so love for this game to be revived. It deserves a place in the BR genre once again. Whether or not that happens, I'll still be playing, and I hope others will too. 

Positives:
- Simple game mechanics
- Easy to find viable weapons and loot so gunfights are more balanced since both sides are using the same weapons
- Games play at your own pace, whether that be fast or slow
- Vast numbers of different clothing and weapon skins
- Semi-easy for new players to pick up and compete in gunfights
- Just really fun to play!

Negatives:
- Abuse of skill-less game mechanics (i.e. shotgun rushing from vehicles, ENS bullet dodging)
- Hit detection and desync
- Inconsistencies with shotgun damage and AR spam firing accuracy
- Glitches/exploits that are abused and not fixed (i.e. shooting out of the back of the ARV)
- Spawning (games with many players could have you spawn over an area with next to no POI or loot, whereas games with sometimes as few as 1 other team can have you spawn over the centre of pleasant valley!)

All in all, I would 100% still recommend this game. You love to hate it! :)

This game used to be fun when it was just H1Z1. I recall playing this game for hours at a time with friends and enjoying every minute of it. Even after the developers made the questionable decision to split their game into two with a battle royale mode and a survival mode, I still enjoyed playing the two games and have very fond memories of the memes that were had in both. Unfortunately the developers have tried to keep up with other games in the battle royale genre by destroying the things that made their game unique and popularized it in the first place. All of this in a feudal attempt to assimilate with the likes of PUBG and Fortnite. It's a shame that the developers fell down this path and will ultimately be rendered a footnote in the battle royale/survival games genre, a once great game that had a tragic fall from grace into the dumpster fire where it exists now.

Original Review:
Look, I understand the complaints about this not being a very polished game, it's early access. 
However, putting all things aside, this game is extremely addictive and fun. The premise is simple enough, there aren't too many items and weapons to make it complicated to choose what gear you need, the learning curve is low and I can happily say I've dumped 21 hours (with more to come) into this game within a very short amount of time. 

I think it's definitely a great multiplayer choice to look into if you're in the mood for something new. Especially great with friends. (Duos and teams of 3-5).

My real wish for future development is that they remember H1Z1 started off as a zombie game and add additional game modes like the current ones, only with zombies spread across the map as well. Right now, bows and melee weapons are basically useless so zombies could reintroduce some different tactics to the game.
